MR. LAIRD AND SOME OF HIS FRIENDS

Aside from the gentlemen who are supporting Mr. Laird because they believe he will be a good minister, there are some of their previous opponents who are now supporting him on his retention. The record shows that Mr. Laird has been a good minister, and he deserves our support.

PRACHING VS. PRACTICE

Electors of Saskatchewan, please make sure that your votes are cast in the proper manner. We urge all electors to vote for the Conservative candidates. The Liberals have not been able to provide for the needs of the people, and we urge all electors to vote for the Conservative candidates.

ADDRESS

To the Electors of Saskatchewan

Gentlemen:

At the request of a number of friends in the District of Saskatchewan, I beg to offer myself as a candidate for your suffrages at the coming election of a member for the Federal Parliament.

Should I be returned as your representative I shall use every endeavor to secure the local interests of the District, and shall urge the Government in the necessity of pushing on Railway communication to Prince Albert, Battleford and Saskatoon;

The building of a bridge across the South Saskatchewan River;

The granting of assistance to the railway to Hudson's Bay;

The more liberal issue of scrip to all children of Halfbreed heads of Families born in the Territories between 1879 and 1885.

The consideration of the permit system by patronizing the liquor question to the popular vote;

The speedy payment on a liberal scale of all just claims against the Government; and

The granting of seed grain free on account of the peculiar circumstances attending the settlers of this district were joined;

The amendment of the Land Acts in such manner as to secure compensation to homesteaders;

The granting of positions under Government to local men;

The purchasing of supplies for public institutions within the district in which they are consumed;

The formation of a Legislative Assembly for the Territories in which Saskatchewan shall have full and proper representation.

As a local man whose interests are closely connected with those of Saskatchewan, I appeal to every elector in the district for support during the coming contest.

I am, gentlemen,

Your obedient servant,

D. H. Macdowall

Aux Plébiscites du District de Saskatchewan.

Messieurs:

A la demande d'un nombre d'amis du District de Saskatchewan, j'ai bien l'honneur de me faire élire candidat; je vous prie de voter pour moi à l'élection prochaine d'un membre pour le Parlement fédéral.

Si je devais être élu représentant, je ferai tout mon possible pour assurer les intérêts locaux du District et je serais heureux de voir le gouvernement agir sur la nécessité de mettre en œuvre les communications ferroviaires avec Prince Albert, Battleford et Saskatoon;

La construction d'un pont sur la Branche Sud de la Saskatchewan;

La facilitation du chemin de fer de la voie ferrée de Hudson's Bay;

La distribution plus libérale de scrip aux enfants des familles Métis nées dans les Territoires depuis 1879 jusqu'en 1885;

La considération particulière du système de permis en soumettant la question de l'alcool à la voix du peuple;

La prompte et libre exécution de toutes justes réclamations pour les propriétaires;

La distribution gratuite des semences distribuées aux cultivateurs de ce district, vu les circonstances particulières dans lesquelles ils se trouvent;

Demander l'Acte des Terres afin de permettre la concentration des établissements;

De nommer des personnes du lieu pour remplir les positions du Gouvernement;

Décharger les marchandises destinées aux travaux publics, dans le district même où elles sont consommées;

De former une Chambre Legislatrice dans les Territoires à laquelle Saskatchewan sera fortement représentée;

Conduire en bonne humeur le local dont les rapports entre les électeurs
Election Notes

On this way, from Troy Mr. Laird held a meeting at Batoche. About forty Halforenites were present, as also Messrs. Stewart (of the N.W. Canada Liberals) Macdonald, Price, Albert, who informed Mr. Laird that the convention would not meet him there; as he had been previously invited by Mr. Laird. There were also present at this meeting Messrs. Craig, Gunn, T. Baker, Brooks, and others, of the Liberal Conservative Association. He gave them a speech in the best style, layouts for a few minutes, and spoke at some length through an interpreter. He charged Sir John Macdonald with playing too close to Indians, and sirになっているな、さんはなりしているのがたくさんいたのです。
